nodes.bodyText: We don't normally use null. In general the codebase assumed all objects are not null. If an object could be null, use Optional<T> explicitly.

Do you really want a bounded varchar type of max length? I think either an unbounded varchar type (UNBOUNDED_LENGTH) or get the max length of all values from enumMap and use varchar(maxValueLength) would make more sense. Also, static import from AbstractVarcharType.

nodes.bodyText:
each parameter on a separate line.
    super(
            length,
            new TypeSignature(...
remove this.

This logic should be in BuiltInFunctionNamespaceManager. FunctionManager should delegate function resolution to the FunctionNamespaceManager managing the specific function namespace. There should be no special handling necessary.
went for a different approach using type constraints so I can have static function signatures here

I don't like special cases. It doesn't feel necessary. For database people, this behavior would be very unexpected. Either support orderable, or not. I think both are reasonable. The result of enum'A' > enum'B' might not make sense but that's ok I think.
I implemented full comparison eventually

First of all, what is udt? I guess it's "user defined type". But the abbreviation is not obvious at all. So do not use it. Also FunctionImplementation has special meanings. If you search in this class, function implementation for builtin function means a java method handle. This is not a function implementation. This logic should be wrapped in BuiltinFunctionNamespaceManager.getFunctions. That way the function resolution for enum operators work the same way as function resolution works for all other functions. Just put the logic there, you don't need a function for this (thus avoid the naming issues).
going for a different approach where I can have static function signatures with a type constraint instead.
We normally use static import, so static import TINYINT, SMALLINT, etc.

I think you can just do
... = ImmutableSet.of(
            TINYINT.getTypeSignature(),
            SMALLINT.getTypeSignature(),
            INTEGER.getTypeSignature(),
            BIGINT.getTypeSignature());
We don't normally use nullable parameters. Use Optional<Type> instead.
noneMatch(EnumType.class::isInstance)

I don't think you need PolymorphicScalarFunction here. This is for special cases where there are multiple physical implementation of the same logical function (the same function signature has multiple java implementations). I don't think you need that for enum operator functions. So I think you can just create an abstract EnumSqlScalarFunction and override specialize to provide the implementation.
What does NONE mean?

nodes.bodyText:
NONE means no enum type constraint.
The reason I'm not using null to express "no enum type constraint" is because I wanted to add an enumTypeConstraint parameter with a default value to the @interface TypeParameter, but null is not accepted as a default value for @interface parameters.
If you think that looks weird, I could make separaate @interfaces instead like LongEnumTypeParameter and VarcharEnumTypeParameter

You can keep the EnumTypeConstraint in TypeVariableConstraint if you need to distinguish between LongEnumType and VarcharEnumType and use @Nullable if you wish.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -116,8 +116,12 @@ To make our previous example work with any type we need the following:
   The ``@TypeParameter`` annotation is used to declare a type parameter which can
   be used in the argument types ``@SqlType`` annotation, or return type of the function.
   It can also be used to annotate a parameter of type ``Type``. At runtime, the engine
-  will bind the concrete type to this parameter. ``@OperatorDependency`` may be used
-  to declare that an additional function for operating on the given type parameter is needed.
+  will bind the concrete type to this parameter. Optionally, the type parameter
+  can be constrained to descendants of a particular type by providing a ``typeBound``
+  to ``@TypeParameter``. This constraint is similar to the bounded type parameter construct

nodes.bodyText: If you prefer to use the word bound, I think this is better named as boundTo / boundedBy. (Only for annotation, you can keep typeBound in TypeVariableConstraint.
I like boundedBy – I like the word bound for consistency with https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/generics/bounded.html

You might want to modify the comment on line 433 as well. Maybe just change it to something generic as // Handle qualified name. Then add additional comment for // Check whether the qualifiedName is a column reference and here you can just say // Check whether the qualifiedName is an enum literal
Also the error thrown probably need to be changed as well. If you look at missingAttributeException it says "column .. cannot be resolved", which is no longer accurate.

Hmm, I do want to keep some of that phrasing since most of the time that will be correct (it's more likely that people are misspelling a column name than an enum literal).
What about: Column or qualified name '%s' cannot be resolved ?

Maybe just say Cannot resolve '%s'. When you tell people what cannot be resolved they'd know whether they meant it to be a column or enum. I agree that most of the time it's probably a column, but whenever it's not this would be a really confusing error message. (People might not know what's a qualified name so we might as well skip that confusion.)

That sounds reasonable – one thing though: there's tons of tests that need updating if we change that message, as many currently expect to see that particular error message.
I can update those, but I'm worrying that we might break tests for other plugins/clients that are not in this repo if we change the error message. What do you think?
After discussion, keeping "Column %s cannot be resolved" only when the qualifiedName has a single part
the function should directly take qualifiedName rather than the node.

toString is not safe here. node.getBase() potentially can be any expression. So you really want the input of this function to be just the QualifiedName and you want to use QualifiedName.getPrefix() here.

These functions ideally should all just take QualifiedName if DereferenceExpression is used, either get QualifiedName from it, or you need to check the base is an Identifier. Blindly use toString is error prune.
I'm keeping the signature as-is because most of the callsites would have to extract the QualifiedName otherwise, but I'm following your suggestion to parse the QualifiedName inside the method.
Either put validation that the node is a valid enum, or make sure only valid enum can be used to call this. I think this function should call isEnumLiteral.

Do we foresee more usage of these newly added helper functions? If the only place we will need this is in FunctionParserHelper I prefer to directly inline this rather than defining more helper functions. Also Signature is in spi so these functions will be visible for all connectors as well.

Let's not do this. You can add a flag to enable / disable this at the very least. This logic doesn't belong here. Please keep interfaces clean.
The way I prefer would be to change the implementation of rewriteIdentifiersToSymbolReferences and add a rewriteDereference to check if (base instanceof Identifier) return node;
this direction ended up being pretty complicated to get tests working, so instead I'm going for a test file that uses a full-fledged DistributedQueryRunner to execute enum tests
I think our naming convention would be to name this class AbstractTestEnum
These are not functions, so why are we using assertFunction 😂

nodes.bodyText: Hmm, so if enum types are qualified, as in catalog.schema.enumtype.enumvalue the part you should get is size()-2, not 0.
This should be getSuffix()
It's the second to the last part that you are looking for. I'd do qualifiedName.getPrefix().getSuffix() here. Or get the size of get(size - 2).
use tryResolveEnumLiteral to be consistent with tryResolveField

Sorry, my previous recommendation was wrong. You actually should just use parseTypeSignature(qualifiedName.getPrefix()) here. If the enum literal is of the form catalog.schema.EnumType.EnumValue, then the type should be catalog.schema.EnumType, rather than just EnumType alone.
In what situation would the nodeType be enum but qualifiedName is null or of the wrong format?
I don't think this should happen – will use requireNonNull instead

This function is too low level to throw an SemanticException. If you expect this function to be only called when node is a valid enum, it should throw IllegalArgumentException. You can change these logic to a checkArgument.

Is it OK to have errors triggered by a checkArgument surfaced to users?
This is the only place where we check whether the provided key exists in the enum, so it will be very possible that users see this error.
If it's not OK, we should add a catch at the correct level and translate the IllegalArgumentException to a SemanticException.
nit: Either put the whole statement in one line or break at both ? and :.

I think you should just have a checkArgument(enumType instanceof LongEnumType || enumType instanceof VarcharEnumType, format("Unsupported enumType '%s (%s)'", enumType, enumType.class)) at the beginning of the function. We normally do validation first.
Why are we removing a plan sanity checker?

nodes.bodyText: Why don't we just return a GenericLiteral here, or if necessary, create a Literal that suits enum. It's a literal, why are we rewriting it to cast?
Let's remove this?

I believe we said we did want to support enum values in ORDER BY clauses?
(but we wanted to possibly implement ordering based on the keys as opposed to the values, and control it with a session param)
I'd assume if we set EnumType as comparable = false, orderable = true things will just work? Do we really need special handling?
if we set comparable = false, we get semantic errors when we write things like mood.happy = mood.happy or use GROUP BY my_enum_column

Hmm, let's just keep both true then? While it doesn't make much sense to do enum >= value I don't really see a problem allowing it either, compare to the other option of inventing some new rules about type out of the spec.
I think we should make the TypeSignature of enum types to include the information that they are enums.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -201,7 +210,9 @@ private static boolean isValidJsonObjectKeyType(Type type)
                 baseType.equals(StandardTypes.REAL) ||
                 baseType.equals(StandardTypes.DOUBLE) ||
                 baseType.equals(StandardTypes.DECIMAL) ||
-                baseType.equals(StandardTypes.VARCHAR);
+                baseType.equals(StandardTypes.VARCHAR) ||
+                type instanceof LongEnumType ||

nodes.bodyText: Conceptually this should not be in default... TypeSignature for enum types should work properly.
This is not necessary. Optional<> would be either empty (null) or non-null.

I will actually remove this logic with the optional name altogether. this was mainly to help users with debugging but there will have to be code elsewhere to catch those errors anyway, so we can log the name of the offending enum at that point instead of here.
We usually just assume input are non-null. Usually we only check requireNonNull at constructor. Functions that expect null would use Optional. Otherwise it should not be invoked with null input.

Probably should check this in the constructor rather than here. Making sure the enum map is valid is the job of enum type constructor. It's fine if you want to have a separate utility function to check that. But for normalizeEnumEntries, it should just assume the input is already a valid enum.
Same here. Maybe you want to just add a validateEnum utility function.
going for a separate validateEnumMap method
Feels that upper case makes more sense? Most enum names are defined in uppercase right?
space after %s before cannot
but then if the name is empty we end up with two spaces between "Enum" and "cannot" in the error msg
I guess then we have to have two error messages and handle them separately.
removing the optional name argument

Feels like this class and the LongEnumMap should be inner class of VarcharEnumType and LongEnumType respectively (or maybe the parametric type versions). They don't make much sense as standalone classes.

It might be cleaner VarcharEnumType and LongEnumType should directly take VarcharEnumMap and LongEnumMap as input. That way you can wrap the validation into those classes and there's no need to validate them again.

This is a minor issue: Seems like you are always calling isEnumLiteral and resolveEnumLiteral together and then you can checking isEnumLiteral here again. So maybe worth have a tryResolveEnumLiteral that returns a Optional<Object> to avoid calling isEnumLiteral twice.
ha that's what I was doing before and you told me to change it to a precondition check 😆 – changing back

Ya, i kinda feel like i probably suggested this 🤦‍♀️. You can keep the isEnumLiteral function. This is more to suggest to only call 1 function at the call sites rather than changing this implementation (other than changing the return type to optional).
Maybe you can incorporate this into the switch (baseType) part now?
how do you mean? inside the default case?
Oh nvm, I thought now the baseType would have "enum" in it.
Can we add tests for all enum operators?
done!
You can remove this. the isEnumLiteral function already checks this. Or move it after the if statement.
